title: Discovery gives Saturn the most moons of any planet in our solar system and prompts name contest
text:
A major discovery will see Saturn dethrone Jupiter as our solar system's title-holder for most moons.

Astronomers from International Astronomical Union's Minor Planet Center spotted 20 previously unknown moons, putting the planet's total to 82 -- three more over Jupiter's total of 79.

According to astronomers, the moons are similar in size -- about five kilometers in diameter -- and the vast majority, 17, of them orbit the ringed planet in retrograde, against the rotation of the planet on its axis.

A newly discovered bevy of moons has been discovered orbiting Saturn, making it the title-holder for most moons in our solar system

The discovery, say astronomers, may help to glean even more information on the planet and its formation.

'Studying the orbits of these moons can reveal their origins, as well as information about the conditions surrounding Saturn at the time of its formation,' said Carnegie Institution for Science's Scott S. Sheppard, who lead the team of astronomers that made the discovery.

Similar to their discovery of a dozen moons orbiting Jupiter last year, the team will now host a public contest designed to name the newest additions to Saturn's bevy of moons.

Participants are being welcomed to submit names having to do with either Norse or Gallic mythology via Carnegie's online form.

Researchers noted that the formation of the retrograde moons indicates that they were likely once apart of a larger moon that was fractured.

'This kind of grouping of outer moons is also seen around Jupiter, indicating violent collisions occurred between moons in the Saturnian system or with outside objects such as passing asteroids or comets,' said Sheppard.

Two of the moon's discovered orbiting the planet (pictured above) are prograde -- meaning the spin in the same direction as Saturn on its axis -- and take two years to travel around the planet

Additionally, researchers say the moons were likely created after the planet was mostly formed given their proximity.

'In the Solar System’s youth, the Sun was surrounded by a rotating disk of gas and dust from which the planets were born. It is believed that a similar gas-and-dust disk surrounded Saturn during its formation,' Sheppard said.

'The fact that these newly discovered moons were able to continue orbiting Saturn after their parent moons broke apart indicates that these collisions occurred after the planet formation process was mostly complete and the disks were no longer a factor.'
